div.head: 1. Diplomatic transcriptions represent the spelling, punctuation, layout, and revisions as they appear, with minimal editorial intervention or interpretation.
div.p:
1.1. Spelling
1.1.1. The original spelling in both manuscripts and typescripts is retained, even if irregular (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin with Typescript W. H. Auden "Freedom and Necessity in the Arts" 1970-05-21, page 9, line 8).
1.1.2. Signs that cannot be transcribed with certainty are marked up as 'unclear' (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1973-09-24, page 3, line 9).
1.1.3. Manuscript signs are not marked up as 'unclear' when they can be identified as a consistent and typical feature of the respective author's handwriting (example: "address", Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1968-10-15, page 3, line 25).
1.1.4. Signatures are not marked up as 'unclear'.
1.1.5. Signs that cannot be transcribed are marked up as 'illegible' (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1968-10-12, page 3, line 7).

1.2. Punctuation and Spaces
1.2.1. The original punctuation and spaces are retained, even if irregular (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1968-10-12, page 3, line 4).
1.2.2. Punctuation signs that cannot be transcribed with certainty are marked up as 'unclear' and rendered by symbols that represent a graphical approximation (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1965-09-29, page 3, line 16).
1.2.3. When spaces before or after punctuation marks are significantly smaller than the spaces separating words in the surrounding text, no spaces are transcribed (example: Letter W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1962-09-11, page 3, line 12).
1.2.4. In manuscripts, the length of spaces between words is regularized (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1968-10-12, page 3, line 6).
1.2.5. In typescripts, the number of spaces is preserved (example: Typescript Stella Musulin "In Retrospect" [?], page 1, line 2).
1.3. Original line breaks and divisions between blocks of text are retained.

1.4. Revisions
1.4.1. The transcriptions represent deletions, additions, and corrections (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1964-12-23, page 3, line 26).
1.4.2. For overwritings in typescripts, we have accepted the orthographically or grammatically accurate versions as corrections, even if the actual sequences of textual layers cannot be reconstructed (example: Typescript Stella Musulin "In Retrospect" [?], page 1, line 27).

1.5. Pre-printed Components and Postal Additions
1.5.1. Pre-printed letter heads and sender addresses are transcribed (example: Autograph Letter Signed W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1968-10-06, page 2, lines 1-3).
1.5.2. Image captions in postcards are transcribed (example: Autograph Note Signed Michael O'Sullivan to Stella Musulin [?], page 1, lines 1-2, 12-15).
1.5.3. Postmarks and stamps are not transcribed.
1.5.4. Pre-printed postal text and images in telegrams and aerograms are not rendered in the transcriptions (example: Telegram W. H. Auden to Stella Musulin 1971-05-13).

div.head: 2. Reading views represent regularized versions of diplomatic transcriptions.
